I may be wrong, but I noticed a possible bug: `BoundedCassandraSource.splitQuery` is set to a split query in `splitIntoBundles` but is never read. Indeed in `reader.start()`, only the query provided by the user (`session.execute(spec.getQuery())`) is used. As a consequence, the input data is never split. IMHO what should be done is to "mix" the split query and the user query and use this mixed query in the reader. @jbonofre As you where coding a query parser, it might be included in the code.

I totally agree that returning `null` here is far from ideal.
See also the [mail thread](https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/79d78e8e114ac97e804f2c01570419404983d6fe40540471698c07c6@%3Cdev.beam.apache.org%3E) and thoughts on [BEAM-849](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-849).

That said, at the moment this `null` is ["according to spec":](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/PipelineResult.java#L54)

```java
/**
   * @return The final state of the pipeline or null on timeout.
   * @throws UnsupportedOperationException if the runner does not support cancellation.
   */
  State waitUntilFinish(Duration duration);
```

I guess it boils down to whether we want to deviate from the SDK spec here.
Please add a new unit test to catch the regression here.

Well, I've hit this when playing around with streaming pipelines (tests) that assert on the result state and it will always return `null` even if all goes brilliantly well (you might expect `DONE`).

I think the final state of the pipeline should be `DONE` after returning from "awaitTermination..." because Spark either finished by then or throws an exception.. `null` is not in Spark's spec, and `SparkPipelineResult` will still return `null` in case of a `TimeoutException`. 

Eventually, the current state is effectively "hard-coded" to always return `null` - and this is wrong according to the Beam spec as well.

Also, I think there is also a problem in `getOrCreateTable`:

```
Exception: java.io.IOException: Unable to get table: streamdemo, aborting after 9 retries.
org.apache.beam.sdk.io.gcp.bigquery.BigQueryServicesImpl.executeWithRetries(BigQueryServicesImpl.java:869)

Caused By: com.google.api.client.googleapis.json.GoogleJsonResponseException: 404 Not Found
{
  "code" : 404,
  "errors" : [ {
    "domain" : "global",
    "message" : "Not found: Table ",
    "reason" : "notFound"
  } ],
  "message" : "Not found: Table "
}
com.google.api.client.googleapis.json.GoogleJsonResponseException.from(GoogleJsonResponseException.java:146)
com.google.api.client.googleapis.services.json.AbstractGoogleJsonClientRequest.newExceptionOnError(AbstractGoogleJsonClientRequest.java:113)
com.google.api.client.googleapis.services.json.AbstractGoogleJsonClientRequest.newExceptionOnError(AbstractGoogleJsonClientRequest.java:40)
com.google.api.client.googleapis.services.AbstractGoogleClientRequest$1.interceptResponse(AbstractGoogleClientRequest.java:321)
com.google.api.client.http.HttpRequest.execute(HttpRequest.java:1065)
```

Come to think about it, can `javaStreamingContext.awaitTerminationOrTimeout(duration.getMillis())` ever return `true` in this context?
Well... if _something_ caused it to close the context before timeout.
But that is not relevant. Even if this is a bug, branch-1.6 is not expected to be further developed and we shouldn't count on it.

retest this please

I think I understand the motivation.
Though if `awaitTermination` always returns `DONE` in streaming mode we will no longer be able to tell whether the waiting was completed successfully or due to a time out. Is this something we care about?
Won't a timeout throw a TimeoutException ?

I think that `StreamingContext#awaitTerminationOrTimeout()` will throw only if there were errors during execution, `true` if stopped before the given duration elapsed, and `false` otherwise.

Or as `Spark` puts it: "true if it's stopped; or throw the reported error during the execution; or false if the waiting time elapsed before returning from the method."

R: @dhalperi 
CC: @reuvenlax

getTable() fix is sent as a separate PR

Pretty sure the future you used there will throw `TimeoutException` if Spark, for some reason, has not returned - so you'd still end up with `null` state in that case (catch clause in SparkPipelineResult).
@reuvenlax I retested this and it is running against head.  I believe it to be ready for another review by @dhalperi .

--none--
Thanks for the review!
LGTM
Please create a JIRA and update the PR description.

If memory serves, if it's a streaming pipeline the future is only responsible for starting the pipeline and will return right away (as opposed to the batch mode, where it actually blocks). Then, it's the `javaStreamingContext.awaitTerminationOrTimeout(duration.getMillis())` that's blocking in `SparkPipelineResult#awaitTermination()`.

Let's take a deeper look tomorrow to make sure.

R: @bjchambers 

We'll want more, but thought I would submit early and often. Any particular suggestions based on these?
r: @robertwb if this looks fine to you, could you merge? : )

I think that requiring test authors to write wait_until_finished() is quite error prone. Perhaps we could make the test runner "blocking" by default (but parametrizable of course). There is no contract that p.run() return immediately, just that it can return early to provide a nicer API.

@robertwb Thank you, I agree that, it is easy to miss `wait_until_finished()` in tests.

I made the `TestDataflowRunner` blocking, but most tests also run with `DirectRunner`. Are you suggesting to make `DirectRunner` blocking by default?
